title: 109_hr5939
content:
The Act may be cited as the "Criminal Terrorism Improvements Act of 2006" and includes provisions related to terrorist offenses resulting in death. The "Criminal Terrorism Improvements Act of 2006" amends Chapter 113B of title 18, United States Code, by adding a new section, Sec. 2339E, which addresses terrorist offenses resulting in death. It states that anyone who causes the death of a person while committing a terrorist offense shall face the death penalty or life imprisonment. The term "terrorist offense" is defined as a felony offense that falls under specific criteria outlined in the section. The term "terrorist offense" is defined in Section 2339E of the Criminal Terrorism Improvements Act of 2006 as a felony offense that includes specific federal crimes of terrorism or attempts to commit such offenses. The Criminal Terrorism Improvements Act of 2006 defines a "terrorist offense" as a felony offense involving federal crimes of terrorism or attempts to commit such offenses. Section 2339E of the Act lists specific offenses, including those under sections 175b, 229, or 831 of the Atomic Energy Act of 1954, or section 236 of the same Act. Additionally, any Federal offense that is an attempt or conspiracy to commit the aforementioned offenses is also considered a terrorist offense. A clerical amendment is made to the table of sections in chapter 113B of title 18, United States Code, to reflect these additions. The Criminal Terrorism Improvements Act of 2006 defines "terrorist offense" as a felony involving federal crimes of terrorism. Section 2339E lists specific offenses, including those under the Atomic Energy Act of 1954. Death penalty is imposed for certain terror-related crimes. The Criminal Terrorism Improvements Act of 2006 expands the death penalty to include offenses related to nuclear weapons, missile systems, and radiological dispersal devices. Title 18, United States Code, is amended to include "punished by death or" after "shall be" in various sections related to atomic weapons, radiological dispersal devices, and the Variola virus. SEC. 4. INCREASE IN CERTAIN PENALTIES. Penalties for specific sections of title 18, United States Code, are increased from 20 years to 30 years and from 10 years to 20 years. SEC. 5. MODERNIZATION OF STATE OF MIND REQUIREMENT FOR SECTION 2339C OFFENSES. SEC. 5. MODERNIZATION OF STATE OF MIND REQUIREMENT FOR SECTION 2339C OFFENSES. Section 2339C of title 18, United States Code, is amended by striking "unlawfully and wilfully" and inserting "knowingly". SEC. 6. Amends penalties for providing material support to terrorist groups and receiving military-type training from a foreign terrorist organization. Providing material support now carries a minimum sentence of 10 years or life, with a minimum of 30 years or life if death results. Receiving military-type training carries a sentence of 3 to 15 years. SEC. 7. Denial of federal benefits to convicted terrorists. Sec. 2339F of Chapter 113B of title 18, US Code, states that individuals convicted of a Federal crime of terrorism may be ineligible for Federal benefits as determined by the court. The court may deem individuals convicted of a Federal crime of terrorism ineligible for Federal benefits for a specified period or for life, as defined in the Controlled Substances Act. SEC. 8. Amends wiretap predicate in title 18, United States Code.

SEC. 9. Amends section 2339D to include attempts and conspiracies related to military training.
